entry.title: Daily Review
entry.content:
Daily Review for 2019-01-22

Daily report: [2019-01-22 Tue]

TODO Headline Time
ALL Total time 3:17
File time 3:17
Today’s Tasks 2:05
  CS5001 2:05
TODO     CS5001 - Homework #2 2:05
DONE       Programming #3 2:05
Morning Ritual 1:12
TODO   Tea Ceremony 0:07
TODO   Review agenda and calendar 0:05
TODO   Shower 0:16
TODO   Breakfast 0:44

Summary

In the morning went to doctor’s appointment. In the afternoon I completed all of my programming problems for Homework #2 for CS5001. Did an initial review of homework problems for CS5002.

Problem

Creating functions that has one job and decoupling it’s responsibility to others. Created helper functions to handle user input, calculations etc, thinking about how to change the relationships between functions to be flexible and modular.

Insight

Blocking distractions and protecting my mind.

Tomorrow

Focusing on CS5002 homework assignment and reading.

Completed Tasks

  • DONE Programming #3

  • DONE Initial review of homework problems for CS5002

entry.title: Daily Review
entry.content:
Daily Review for 2019-01-20

Daily report: [2019-01-20 Sun]

TODO Headline Time
ALL Total time 3:48
File time 3:48
Today’s Tasks 3:08
  CS5001 3:08
TODO     CS5001 - Homework #2 3:08
DONE       Initial review of homework programming problems 0:25
DONE       Setting up environment 0:15
DONE       Programming #1 1:38
NEXT       Programming #2 0:50
Morning Ritual 0:40
TODO   Journal writing 0:23
TODO   Review agenda and calendar 0:17

Summary

Dedicated time today to CS5001. Starting my initial review of programming problems from the homework, completing defining the functions and almost complete with the test cases and preparing for the last portion of the assignment where I’m putting it all together.

Problem

Estimating the amount of time it takes to complete a task. Sometimes I may allocate 30min or so for a given task and then I’m consumed by the task and want to spend more time with it and then not dedicating enough time for other tasks.The proper optimal distribution of times for a given task to push a brick forward.

Insight

Before starting a task I estimate the amount of time it will take me to complete the given task. This deliberate planning of estimating my time and logging has kept me focused and accountable.

Tomorrow

To finish writing test cases for the programming component #2. To complete programming problem #3 for CS5001. To dedicate time tomorrow to review this week’s material for CS5002. To complete all of the problems for CS5002 and get started on the Zybook reading.

Completed Tasks

  • DONE Initial review of homework programming problems

  • DONE Setting up environment

  • DONE Programming #1

entry.title: Daily Review
entry.content:
Daily Review for 2019-01-17

Daily report: [2019-01-17 Thu]

TODO Headline Time
ALL Total time 4:23
File time 4:23
Today’s Tasks 3:16
TODO   CS5001 0:50
DONE     Prepare CS5001 homework for submission 0:50
TODO   CS5002 1:41
DONE     Prepare CS5002 homework for submission 1:41
WAITING   Apply for GradPlus loans for 2019-2020 0:42
DONE   Send email to MD about financial aid 0:03
Morning Ritual 1:07
TODO   Meditation 0:11
TODO   Shower 0:23
TODO   Breakfast 0:33

Summary

I finalized the submission of my first homework assignment for both of my classes. Dedicated time to finalizing financial aid and reviewing for today’s lab session.

Problem

For CS5001, I allocated some time this morning making sure style was correct, test cases, and generally good for submission. A good chunk of time trying to setup latex to play nicely with emacs. I was able to get it working but couldn’t get the completion engine, company, to work with the latex symbols. I’m going to try this again at some point in the future so I’m able to submit my homework assignments digitally. I experienced some difficulty with the financial aid office and I’m waiting to hear back.

Insight

To start homework assignments earlier and focus on completing them. I will start using emacs to calculate the amount of effort it takes to complete a given task.

Doing Despite Disliking: Self-regulatory Strategies in Everyday Aversive Activities

Abstract: We investigated the self-regulatory strategies people spontaneously use in their everyday lives to regulate their persistence during aversive activities. In pilot studies (pooled N = 794), we identified self-regulatory strategies from self-reports and generated hypotheses about individual differences in trait self-control predicting their use. Next, deploying ambulatory assessment (N = 264, 1940 reports of aversive/challenging activities), we investigated predictors of the strategies’self-reported use and effectiveness (trait self-control and demand types). The popularity of strategies varied across demands. In addition, people higher in trait self-control were more likely to focus on the positive consequences of a given activity, set goals, and use emotion regulation. Focusing on positive consequences, focusing on negative consequences (of not performing the activity), thinking of the near finish, and emotion regulation increased perceived self-regulatory success across demands, whereas distracting oneself from the aversive activity decreased it. None of these strategies, however, accounted for the beneficial effects of trait self-control on perceived self-regulatory success. Hence, trait self-control and strategy use appear to represent separate routes to good self-regulation. By considering trait- and process-approaches these findings promote a more comprehensive understanding of self-regulatory success and failure during people’s daily attempts to regulate their persistence. © 2018 European Association of Personality Psychology

Tomorrow

To review this week’s material from both CS5001 and CS5001 classes and to marinate the homework released for each class.

Completed Tasks

  • DONE Prepare homework for submission

    • State “DONE” from “NEXT” [2019-01-17 Thu 10:48]
    • State “NEXT” from “TODO” [2019-01-17 Thu 10:45]

  • DONE Prepare CS5002 homework for submission

  • DONE Review this week’s material CS5001

entry.title: Daily Review
entry.content:
Daily Review for 2019-01-16

Daily report: [2019-01-16 Wed]

TODO Headline Time
ALL Total time 3:01
File time 3:01
Today’s Tasks 1:18
DONE   CS5001 0:38
DONE     Homework #1 [5⁄5] 0:38
DONE       Programming #3 - change.py 0:38
DONE   Swimming at the YMCA 0:40
This Week’s Projects 1:20
DONE   Meeting with ER 0:12
DONE   Appointment with JB 1:08
Morning Ritual 0:08
TODO   Breakfast 0:08
Afternoon Ritual 0:15
TODO   Recovery Block 0:15

Summary

Woke up early to the YMCA to swim and had two meetings with my health care providers. I re-looked at change.py and was able to come up with a working solution in the afternoon. Then later had night classes.

Problem

change.py took some time to work on while the other homework problems I was able to complete in a moderately fast time. I believe the lesson learned here, it’s not quite about speed, but focusing more on planning and making sure I have a draft on paper before I start my second draft on a computer. In addition, I realized that I was feeling exhausted the whole day at different times by the time late afternoon arrived.

Insight

When working on a programming problem, regardless of how easy I may perceive the problem to be, start on paper first to at least have an idea. Other thoughts are to possibly change my morning routine so I’m not waking up at 6am everyday, but perhaps the night I have classes I can wake up later.

Tomorrow

To review homework before submission for both classes and review material from CS5001 in preparation for lab

Completed Tasks

  • DONE Swimming at the YMCA

  • DONE Appointment with JB

  • DONE Programming #3 - change.py

  • DONE Meeting with ER

  • DONE Written #1

  • DONE Written #2

  • DONE Written #3

  • DONE Written #4

  • DONE Homework #1 [5⁄5]

  • DONE CS5001 :5001:

  • DONE CS5002 :5002:

  • DONE Review using supplemental material

entry.title: Daily Review
entry.content:
Daily Review for 2019-01-15

Daily report: [2019-01-15 Tue]

TODO Headline Time
ALL Total time 5:43
File time 0:28
File time 5:15
Today’s Tasks 3:51
TODO   CS5001 2:30
TODO     Homework #1 [2⁄7] 2:30
NEXT       Programming #3 - change.py 2:30
TODO   CS5002 1:21
DONE     Zybook Reading 1:21
Morning Ritual 0:36
TODO   Meditation 0:11
TODO   Journal writing 0:15
TODO   Review agenda and calendar 0:10
Bedtime Ritual 0:48
TODO   Admin Block 0:32
TODO   Create functional space 0:16

Summary

Spent the majority of today working on change.py and completing the Zybook reading. I was able to complete the Zybook reading and make progress on change.py. There was some level of friction due to not starting this specific problem on paper.

Problem

Part of the difficulty that I noticed in completing change.py was that I didn’t first attempt to solve it on a piece of paper, but rather jumped into emacs and tried to solve it. Doing it this approach took me a much longer time than anticipated.

Insight

Make sure I have a general schema, outline, notes, worked out the solution somewhat on paper and then on a computer. Using a computer and programming it is equivalent to a second or third draft of writing, in this case code.

Tomorrow

Will take time to review the problem, review test cases, syntax and general style. Will see if I have the time to do office hours.

For CS5002 I will use supplementary sources to review material and in preparation for the upcoming lecture.
